keyTakeAways: The death toll from flooding in central and southeastern Mexico has risen to 44, with some reports citing 48 fatalities.
The flooding was triggered by heavy rains from the remnants of Tropical Storm Raymond and Hurricane Priscilla, affecting five states: Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi.
Specific death tolls by state include 18 in Veracruz, 16 in Hidalgo, 9 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro.
Dozens of people remain missing, and at least 16,000 homes have been damaged, with around 320,000 experiencing power outages.
Mexicoâ€™s President Claudia Sheinbaum activated the military to assist in rescue operations and aid distribution, stating, 'We will not leave anyone without support.'
Photos from the military show evacuations using life rafts, flooded homes, and rescue workers navigating waist-high waters.
This flooding is part of a broader pattern of extreme rainfall in Mexico, with Mexico City experiencing its rainiest June in over two decades.
The remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Storm Raymond contributed to the heavy rains that caused landslides and river overflows.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Severe flooding in central and southeastern Mexico, caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Storm Raymond, has led to at least 44 deaths, with some reports citing 48, and dozens missing. The affected states include Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi, with the highest fatality counts in Veracruz and Hidalgo. Around 320,000 people have lost power and 16,000 homes have been damaged. President Claudia Sheinbaum activated the military to assist in rescue efforts, emphasizing that no one will be left without support. The disaster is part of a broader trend of extreme rainfall in Mexico, including record rainfall in Mexico City, which has raised concerns about climate-related risks.
title: Death toll from Mexico flooding rises to 44, dozens more missing
